title: 114_hr4978
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Nurturing And Supporting Healthy Babies Act" or the "NAS Healthy Babies Act". GAO will report on Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS). The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) to specific committees in Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The report will cover the prevalence of NAS in the US, including the proportion of affected children eligible for Medicaid at birth and associated costs. It will also include information on available services for NAS. The report on neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) will include coverage of services available under State Medicaid programs, treatment settings, reimbursement methodologies, prevalence of care settings, best practices for treatment, and recommendations for improving access to treatment for infants with NAS under State Medicaid programs. SEC. 3. Excludes abuse-deterrent formulations of prescription drugs from Medicaid rebate requirement for new formulations. Effective date applies to drugs paid for by states in calendar quarters after enactment.

SEC. 4. Limits disclosure of predictive modeling and analytics technologies for waste, fraud, and abuse prevention. Title XI of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 1128K, focusing on the disclosure of predictive modeling and analytics technologies to identify and prevent waste, fraud, and abuse. The Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 includes provisions on the use of predictive modeling technologies to prevent fraud in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. Covered algorithms used for this purpose are exempt from disclosure under FOIA. The Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 allows the use of covered algorithms to prevent fraud in Medicaid and CHIP programs. State agencies can only use these algorithms for administering the State plan under the Medicaid program or the State child health plan, including for identifying or preventing waste, fraud, and abuse. State agencies must have data security policies for covered algorithms used in Medicaid and CHIP programs to prevent fraud. Access to information must be restricted to authorized persons, and agencies must follow uniform procedures established by the Secretary. The term 'covered algorithm' is defined in this section. The term 'covered algorithm' refers to predictive modeling or analytics technology used to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. It includes mathematical expressions and development methods. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding Medicaid state plan requirements. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act to require State agencies administering the State plan to provide assurances of compliance with specific sections. This includes provisions related to covered algorithms for preventing waste, fraud, and abuse in healthcare programs. Amendments to the Social Security Act require State agencies to ensure compliance with specific sections, including covered algorithms for preventing waste, fraud, and abuse in healthcare programs. This involves adding a new subparagraph to ensure compliance with certain provisions. The Medicaid Improvement Fund under the Social Security Act is amended to allocate $5,000,000 for expenditures from fiscal year 2021 onwards. This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on May 11, 2016.
